Some key points about Least Square Model

has the unit of , has the unit of Y.

The line passes through the point (,)

The slope of the regression line with X as the outcome and Y as the predictor is Cor(Y,X)Sd(X)/Sd(Y)

The slope is the same one you would get if you centered the data, and did regression through the origin.

If you normalized the data, , the slope is Cor(Y,X) because Sd(X) = Sd(Y) = 1.

Derivation of linear regression equations

The following is adapted from Data Analysis Toolkit #10: Simple linear regression. However, there are some important supplementary information I want to include here.

Regression through the origin

Consider regression through the origin, let’s minimize

which can be expressed as

we can do a second derivative to test

The above formula could be further enhanced to be

Since we could center x and y, therefore

R code examples

 
library(UsingR)
data(galton)
library(dplyr); library(ggplot2)
y <- galton$child
x <- galton$parent
beta1 <- cor(y,x) * sd(y) / sd(x)
beta0 <- mean(y) - beta1 * mean(x)
rbind(c(beta0,beta1), coef(lm(y~x)))
  


    (Intercept)         x
[1,]    23.94153 0.6462906
[2,]    23.94153 0.6462906

The following is simulation with R to prove the above terms are true.


x = c(3,2,4,5,3,2,4,3)
y = c(3,4,2,4,5,3,2,6)
sum((mean(d))^2-d*mean(d))
sum(mean(d)*mean(e)-e*mean(d))
